I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The adoption of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) in September 2000 has 
resulted in an increase in demand for reliable and timely statistical data to assess the impact of 
policies designed to attain these goals. The need for reliable and timely statistical data has also 
risen considerably in recent years with adoption of the Managing for Development Results  
approach, which also uses many MDG indicators, by the international development community 
to monitor development outcomes. Many MDG indicators are compiled from household surveys 
that are infrequently conducted. In many countries, the time interval between household surveys 
could be longer than 5 or 10 years, while, in some Pacific countries, household surveys would 
be conducted only if supported by donor funding. In addition, survey-based MDG data tend to be 
reported at the national level only due to the small survey sample size. Thus, it may not be 
possible  to  assess  progress  made  towards  attaining  the  MDGs  regularly  or  by  various 
subgroups of the population.     
 
2.  In principle, many MDG indicators can also be compiled from administrative data, which 
are data collected by the line ministries of a country as part of the programs and policies 
implemented by those ministries. Administrative data represent a potentially rich and alternative 
source for compiling these MDG indicators as, compared to survey data, they are collected 
much more frequently and at a much lower cost. Such data can also be presented at various 
levels of disaggregation, such as by geographical location or by gender. In many developing 
member countries (DMCs), however, administrative data are underutilized in the reporting of 
MDG indicators, as such data tend to be biased by misreporting and incomplete coverage. To 
strengthen the capacity of DMCs in using administrative data for compiling and monitoring MDG 
indicators,  this  regional  technical  assistance  (RETA)  is  proposed  to  assess  existing 
administrative data reporting systems in selected DMCs, clearly identify the key problems with 
these systems, make recommendations for improvements in the use of the systems, encourage 
the governments to make effective use of the administrative data, and develop a manual on the 
use of administrative data for compiling MDG indicators.1 The RETA design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Each MDG indicator is monitored according to a standard international definition by one 
or  more  designated  lead  international  agencies,  such  as  the  United  Nations  Educational, 
Scientific and Cultural Organization; World Bank; and World Health Organization. Many MDG 
indicators are derived from household survey data. Due to the relatively small sample size of 
existing household surveys, such survey-based MDG indicators are only reported at the national 
level. Further, they are reported on an ad hoc basis due to the infrequent nature of these 
surveys.      
 
4.  There  are,  however,  at  least  three  potential  shortcomings  in  the  current  method  of 
reporting survey-based MDG indicators. First, there is an increasing need for MDG indicators to 
be compiled in DMCs at the subnational level so that key areas or groups that need intervention 
can be readily identified. However, using existing household surveys to compile disaggregated 
data for MDG indicators is likely to result in large sampling errors and render the results 
unreliable. On the other hand, reducing the large sampling errors will require a substantial 
increase in the sample size for these surveys and a corresponding increase in their costs. 
Second, there has been an increase in demand for MDG indicators in DMCs to be reported

more frequently, say, annually, and in a more timely manner so that policies can be formulated 
and implemented more quickly to address and tackle any unsatisfactory progress made towards 
attaining any MDG indicator.  Ad hoc household surveys will not be able to satisfy such demand, 
unless they are conducted annually. Moreover, there is a rather long lag between the time the 
results of household surveys are processed and the estimates for MDG indicators released. 
Increasing  the  frequency  of  household  surveys,  however,  may  result  in  a  corresponding 
significant increase in their costs. Allocating more budget to household surveys in many DMCs 
is not a viable solution to the highlighted issues, given the relatively low priority accorded to 
statistical activities by their governments. Nor will it address substantially the time lag problem 
associated  with  these  surveys.  Three,  in  the  context  of  a  basic  results  chain  framework, 
household surveys are useful for compiling impact or outcome indicators, while administrative 
data are considered more relevant for compiling input and output indicators.  Many countries 
tend to focus on the former and neglect the latter. However, it may not be possible to assess 
thoroughly the effectiveness of development interventions without completing the basic results 
chain with input and output indicators. 
 
5.  The  above  issues  can  be  addressed  by  using  administrative  data  collected  by  the 
appropriate line agencies to compile many of the MDG indicators, especially those related to 
education, health, and mortality. This is because, unlike household surveys, administrative data 
(i) involve a lower respondent burden, (ii) are collected more frequently, (iii) are less costly to 
collect and process, and (iv) can be used to produce more timely MDG indicators at various 
levels of disaggregation without any sampling problems.  
 
6.  However,  problems  such  as  undercoverage,  misreporting,  possible  difficulties  in 
operationalizing the definitions of MDG indicators, and lack of coordination between the national 
statistical offices (NSOs) and line agencies responsible for collecting the administrative data 
mean that, at present, such data are usually not fully exploited in many DMCs to compile MDG 
indicators.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The RETA aims to assist DMCs enhance their capacities to compile and monitor MDG 
indicators in a more timely and regular manner by making improvements in the use of their 
administrative  data  reporting  systems. 2  The  RETA  will  have  two  key  outputs,  namely, 
assessment studies and a manual on the use of administrative data for the compilation of MDG 
indicators.    
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The RETA will cover six DMCs—Mongolia, Nepal, Palau, Sri Lanka, Tajikistan, and Viet 
Nam. The participating DMCs were selected using a variety of criteria, including (i) size of the 
country, (ii) budget considerations, (iii) likelihood that these DMCs have administrative data 
reporting systems that can be used to compile MDG indicators, and (iv) likelihood that their 
administrative data reporting systems are representative of those in the other countries in the 
regions to which they belong.  
 
                                                 
2  This will also help to improve the reporting and monitoring of development outcomes under the Managing for 
Development Results approach.

3
9.  The RETA outputs will be obtained through a combination of (i) consulting services, (ii) 
country consultations, (iii) support for data collection, (iv) assessment and pilot studies, (v) 
analysis, and (vi) dissemination. The RETA will include the following key activities: (i) assessing 
the existing administrative data reporting systems, (ii) recommending improvements in the use 
of  the  systems,  (iii)  implementing  the  recommendations,  (iv)  conducting  training  and  user-
producer workshops on the use of administrative data, and (v) developing a manual on the use 
of administrative data to compile MDG indicators. 
 
1.  Assess Existing Administrative Data Reporting Systems  
 
10.  This component will be carried out in two steps. First, an international consultant will 
review all the MDG indicators and list those which can be compiled from administrative data. A 
review  of  the  experience  in  other  regions,  such  as  Africa  and  Latin  America,  in  using 
administrative data to compile MDG indicators and the evolution of data sources for these 
indicators will also be conducted. Next, in each participating DMC, a national consultant will 
conduct a study (under the guidance and supervision of the international consultant) to assess 
the strengths and weaknesses of the various administrative data reporting systems (such as the 
vital registration as well as health and education management information systems) in terms of 
their  abilities  to  provide  data  to  compute  MDG  indicators  (or  administrative-based  MDG 
indicators) based on such criteria as, among others, (i) attributes of the administrative data 
records, (ii) design of forms for collecting the administrative data, (iii) extent of known data gaps, 
(iv) quality  of data records, (v) availability of databases for storing the administrative data 
records, (vi) ease with which the data can be used to operationalize the definitions of the MDG 
indicators, and (vii) level of statistical training received by the staff in the line agencies owning 
the systems. Each study will also determine (i) the extent to which administrative data are 
currently being used to compile estimates of MDG indicators; (ii) the extent of coordination 
between the owners of the administrative data systems and the NSO in the production of these 
statistics; (iii) the extent of and reasons for the differences between administrative- and survey-
based MDG indicators; (iv) whether the statistics are reported to the lead international agencies 
concerned;  and  (iv)  the  extent  of  past,  current,  and  planned  assistance  from  the  lead 
international agencies to improve the administrative data reporting systems. The assessment 
studies will be conducted using information already available at Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
and  on  the  Internet  websites  of  the  lead  international  agencies,  in  addition  to  information 
provided by the participating DMCs through e-mail, telephone calls, or visits to the appropriate 
line agencies, if necessary.   
 
2.  Recommend Improvements in the Use of Administrative Data  
 
11.  Using the results of the assessment studies, the national consultants, in consultation with 
the international consultant and with the NSOs and line agencies in their respective countries, 
will prepare recommendations to improve the use of these systems to generate administrative-
based MDG indicators. These will include, among others, (i) developing appropriate statistical 
techniques and methods to deal with problems such as undercoverage and misreporting, ensure 
the administrative-based MDG indicators are compiled according to the respective standard 
international definitions, and reconcile these indicators with those obtained from household 
surveys; (ii) preparing appropriate templates to collect data which conform to the standard 
international definitions of the indicators; (iii) developing a system of checks and balances to

3.  Implement Recommendations  
 
12.  In each participating DMC, the proposed recommendations will be pilot-tested for a few 
administrative-based MDG indicators. The results will be analyzed and, where appropriate, 
cross-checked with existing survey-based estimates. After that, the recommendations will be 
fine-tuned before they are extended to the rest of the administrative-based MDG indicators, with 
appropriate modifications made to accommodate the different features of the administrative data 
reporting systems in these DMCs. Particular attention will be paid to ensure that the finalized 
statistical techniques and methods produce estimates for administrative-based MDG indicators 
that can be harmonized with the survey-based ones. In addition, as the implementation of these 
recommendations will most likely require the use of administrative data records to produce 
backdated estimates of administrative-based MDG indicators for analysis and assessment, it will 
be conducted in close collaboration with the line agencies.   
 
4.  Conduct User-Producer and Training Workshops 
 
13.  User-producer workshops will be held in each participating DMC to discuss the results of 
the implementation component and gather feedback on the validity of the results. Training 
workshops will be organized to train the staff of the line agencies and NSOs on the appropriate 
use of administrative data to produce administrative-based MDG indicators according to the 
standard international definitions and on how to analyze, report and monitor the results.4   
 
5.  Develop Manual on Use of Administrative Data to Compile MDG Indicators 
 
14.  This component will develop a manual on the use of administrative data to compute 
MDG indicators. This MDG indicators manual will be written in close consultation with key 
stakeholders, such as the NSOs and line agencies in the participating DMCs and the respective 
lead international agencies for the MDG indicators. Among other things, the manual will include 
guidelines on how to validate the data as well as statistical techniques and methods to correct 
for undercoverage and misreporting in the systems; adjust the data so that they conform to the 
standard international definitions of the respective indicators; and ensure harmonization of the 
estimates computed using administrative data and household survey data. The manual will also 
include samples of templates for collecting data that can be readily used to operationalize the 
definitions of the indicators.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The  total  cost  of  the  RETA  is  estimated  to  be  $500,000.  This  includes  consulting 
services, country visits, assessment and pilot studies, as well as workshops. The RETA will be 
financed on a grant basis from ADB’s technical assistance funding program. The detailed cost 
estimates are given in Appendix 2.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the RETA, while its administration will be handled 
by the Economics and Research Department (ERD). The RETA will be implemented from 
January  2007  to  December  2008.  Where  appropriate,  it  will  be  implemented  in  close 
consultation with the Poverty Unit of the Regional and Sustainable Development Department 
and lead international agencies so as to avoid any overlap of activities. NSOs in the participating 
DMCs will also be consulted in order to tap their institutional knowledge of the statistical systems 
in their respective countries. The regional departments will be kept updated on the progress of 
the RETA through meetings of the Technical Working Group on Statistical Capacity Building, 
which comprises staff of ERD and the regional departments, and by e-mail to its members. 
 
17.  The  RETA  will  finance  35  person-months  of  consulting  services:  1  international 
consultant  (5  person-months)  and  6  national  consultants  (5  person-months  each).  The 
consultants will be selected and engaged individually, according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (April 2006, as amended from time to time). The terms of reference for the 
consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
18.  The national consultants, in consultation with ERD and the line agencies and NSOs of 
the participating DMCs, will undertake the country assessment studies, make recommendations 
for  improvements,  implement  the  recommendations,  and  conduct  local  user-producer  and 
training workshops under the overall guidance of the international consultant.5 The national 
consultants  will  submit  their  reports  within  2  weeks  after  completing  each  portion  of  their 
assignments. An inception meeting involving the international and national consultants will be 
held before the start of the country assessment studies to determine the approach to these 
studies and to preparing the MDG indicators manual. The results and recommendations of the 
country assessment studies, approach to implementing the recommendations, and outline of the 
manual will be discussed at a regional workshop in June 2007. This workshop will be attended 
by high-level officials of the participating DMCs, among others.6 The intention is to secure their 
commitment to implement the recommendations. 
 
19.  The international consultant will consolidate all the results of the various studies and 
prior  workshops  and  prepare  the  draft  MDG  indicators  manual.  The  draft  manual  will  be 
discussed at the RETA concluding workshop in October 2008. The concluding workshop will be 
attended by senior staff of the NSOs and appropriate line agencies of the participating DMCs, 
staff of the regional departments and/or regional missions, international and national consultants, 
and resource persons from the lead international agencies, among others. The international 
consultant will finalize the manual, after incorporating the comments and suggestions of the 
workshop participants, and submit it to ADB by the end of November 2008. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Improving Administrative Data Sources for the Monitoring of the Millennium Development Goal 
Indicators, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE OF CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Statistics Consultant (5 person-months, intermittent) 
1.  The international statistics consultant should have a strong background in statistics 
and/or economics, extensive practical working experience with national statistical offices (NSOs) 
and government agencies that own the administrative data reporting systems in developing 
countries, and extensive knowledge of how Millennium Development Goal (MDG) indicators are 
compiled in developing countries (and especially those in the Asia and Pacific region). The 
consultant will provide the necessary guidance and supervision to the national consultants, who 
will each undertake an assessment study of the administrative data reporting systems, make 
recommendations  for  improvements  to  the  systems,  implement  the  recommendations,  and 
conduct user-producer and training workshops in the participating developing member countries 
(DMCs). Where necessary, he or she will supervise and guide more closely national consultants 
from DMCs with low levels of statistical capacity or perform their tasks if no suitable national 
consultants are available. 
 
2.  In particular, the consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Review all MDG indicators and determine which ones can be generated using 
administrative data records, with an emphasis on the participating DMCs. 
(ii)  Review the experience of other regions (for example, Africa and Latin America) 
in using administrative data to compile MDG indicators. 
(iii)  Review the development of data sources for the compilation of MDG indicators 
since the adoption of the MDGs. 
(iv)  Develop a detailed framework to guide the national consultants in their studies to 
assess  the  strengths  and  weaknesses  of  the  administrative  data  reporting 
systems in the participating DMCs in terms of their ability to provide data to 
generate MDG indicators and present this at the inception meeting organized by 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
(v)  Work with the national consultants to gather information from all sources based 
on the requirements of the framework.  
(vi)  Review  the  results  of  the  assessment  studies  conducted  by  the  national 
consultants and the recommendations made.  
(vii)  Develop  a  comprehensive  framework  to  guide  the  national  consultants  to 
implement the recommendations and validate and improve the results, taking into 
consideration the special circumstances of each participating DMC. 
(viii)  Review  the  results  of  the  implementation  studies  conducted  by  the  national 
consultants and make suggestions for enhancements, where appropriate. 
(ix)  Assist and guide the national consultants in conducting local user-producer and 
training workshops, and provide other needed assistance to regional, local, and 
concluding workshops and other meetings.  
(x)  Prepare an outline for the manual on the use of administrative data to compile 
MDG indicators and present it at the regional workshop organized by ADB. 
(xi)  Prepare the draft manual, taking into consideration the experiences of DMCs in 
using  such  data  to  compile  the  indicators,  and  present  it  at  the  concluding 
workshop organized by ADB. 
(xii)  Submit the final manual and final report to ADB at the end of the assignment.  
(xiii)  Participate in the inception meeting to discuss the approach to the assessment 
studies and preparation of the manual, regional workshop to discuss the findings 
and recommendations of the assessment studies and outline of the manual,

B.  Six National Statistics Consultants (5 person-months each, intermittent) 
3.  The national statistics consultants should have strong backgrounds in statistics and/or 
economics; extensive prior working experience in their respective NSOs and, preferably, in the 
data  collection  and  data  management  departments  of  government  agencies  that  own  the 
administrative data reporting systems; and sufficient practical knowledge of how MDG indicators 
are computed in their respective DMCs. The national consultants should also have the expertise 
to assess the strengths and weaknesses of the administrative data reporting systems in their 
respective DMCs, especially in terms of their capabilities to generate MDG indicators at the 
national and subnational levels, and be proficient in the use of statistical software packages.   
 
4.  Under the overall guidance and supervision of the international consultant, each national 
consultant will 
(i)  Conduct  an  assessment  study  of  the  various  administrative  data  reporting 
systems in his or her country, identifying their strengths and weaknesses in terms 
of their readiness for the compilation of MDG indicators and making appropriate 
recommendations for improvements to the use of the systems. He or she will 
work in close consultation with the NSO and government agencies owning the 
systems. 
(ii)  Submit a report on the findings of the assessment study and recommendations 
(with  due  care  to  ensure  that  these  can  be implemented  in  a  cost-effective 
manner without any substantial overhaul of the administrative data  reporting 
systems) to ADB and present them at the regional workshop organized by ADB.  
Recommendations will include (a) developing appropriate statistical techniques 
and methods to deal with such problems as undercoverage and misreporting, 
compile  administrative-based  MDG  indicators  that  are  consistent  with  the 
standard international definitions and reconcile the estimates with survey-based 
estimates; (b) preparing templates to collect data that conform to the standard 
international definitions of the indicators; (c) developing a system to validate the 
data records; and (d) presenting the subnational data in various categories. 
(iii)  Conduct pilot tests to implement recommendations for a few MDG indicators, 
analyze the results, fine-tune the recommendations, and extend these to the 
other MDG indicators and analyze the results.  
(iv)  Conduct  local  user-producer  workshops  to  discuss  the  results  of  the 
implementation phase  and submit a report on the results to ADB. 
(v)  Conduct local training workshops to train the staff of the NSO and relevant 
government  agencies  to  (a)  implement  the  recommendations  made;  and  (b) 
interpret, analyze and monitor the results. Submit a report to ADB regarding the 
workshops. 
(vi)  Provide inputs to the preparation of the manual on the use of administrative data 
to compile MDG indicators. 
(vii)  Participate in the inception meeting to discuss the approach to the assessment 
studies and preparation of the manual, regional workshop to discuss the findings 
and recommendations of the assessment studies and outline of the manual, 
concluding workshop to discuss the draft manual, as well as other meetings and 
workshops organized by ADB. 
(viii)  Submit a final report to ADB at the end of the assignment.
